section.title: Introduction
section.para: This is a TEI Publisher-based application aggregating the ELTeC literary texts encoded at ELTeC Level 1 (where available) for quick, facetted browsing, visualisation and full text search (see canonical releases of the datasets). All texts included in this collection are in the public domain.

Beyond the direct purpose of presenting the ELTeC corpus texts, the application code itself and this accompanying commentary is intended for self-study by TEI practitioners looking for a case study guide: how to publish a larger corpus of TEI encoded material online.

This work has been inspired by the e-editiones online community discussion under the working title of TEI Vanilla - an effort to ease the learning curve for TEI beginners, particularly those who find themselves in leading roles without much institutional support or prior experience. We hope that an informal narrative on the encoding and development processes and decisions we needed to make will be of use others who face similar challenges.

note.para: ELTeC European Literary Text Collection, version 0.5.0, November 2019, edited by Carolin Odebrecht, Lou Burnard and Christof Schöch. COST Action Distant Reading for European Literary History (CA16204). DOI
ELTeC application was developed by Magdalena Turska and is released under GNU General Public License v3.0.

section.title: Encoding
section.para: ELTeC (European Literary Text Collection) is one of the chief deliverables of EU-funded COST action CA 16204 "Distant Reading", developed between 2017 and 2021 (see further https://www.distant-reading.net/eltec/). Its encoding and design are exhaustively described in a number of working papers; see in particular a short summary paper presented at the TEI 2019 conference in Graz (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3552489).

As noted in that paper, the focus of the ELTeC encoding scheme is not to represent texts in all their original complexity, nor to duplicate the work of scholarly editors, but rather to facilitate a richer and better-informed distant reading than a transcription of lexical content alone would permit. Where the TEI permits diversity, ELTeC enforces consistency, permitting only a specific and quite small set of textual features, both structural and lexical, along with a tightly constrained metadata scheme.

Following this "No Surprises" principle, the simplest ELTeC schema (the level zero schema) provides a bare minimum of tags to mark up the typical structure and content of a nineteenth century novel. All preliminary matter other than the title-page and any authorial preface or introduction is discarded; the remainder is marked as a div of type titlepage or liminal, within a front element. Within the body of a text, the div element is also used to make explicit its structural organization, with type attribute values part, chapter, or letter only. A chapter is considered to be the smallest subsection of a novel within which paragraphs of text appear directly. Further subdivisions within a chapter (often indicated conventionally by ellipses, dashes, stars etc.) are marked using the milestone element; larger groupings of div elements are indicated by div elements, always of type group, whatever their hierarchic level. Headings, at whatever level, are always marked using the head element when appearing at the start of a div, and the trailer element when appearing at the end. Within the div element, only a very limited number of elements is permitted: specifically, in addition to those already mentioned, p or l (verse line). Within these elements we find either plain text, hi (highlighted), pb (page break) or milestone elements. It was agreed that it would be practical to require only this tiny subset of the TEI for all ELTeC texts.

In practice, however, encoders found it both feasible and desirable to expand slightly on this very restricted set of textual distinctions, and the majority of ELTeC corpora use a slightly larger element set, known as eltec level one.

Texts for inclusion in ELTeC came from many different sources. In most, though not all, cases texts were adapted from previously existing digital versions in other formats, typically HTML or ePub, though there were also a few existing (and much richer) TEI versions. In other cases, texts were available only in visual formats (PDF etc.) which had to be retyped or processed with an OCR system. A wide variety of different tools were used.

To facilitate co-operation and consistency of practice, the texts were all stored and managed as a suite of github repositories. As well as syntactic validation of the texts against the ELTeC schema using an XML parser, special purpose XSLT stylesheets were used to check in detail practice across the project, notably as regards the format of metadata in the header.
Training material and workshops were also produced to help would-be contributors to the project: see, for example, Encoding Guide 1 and Encoding Guide 2

note.para: This chapter discusses the steps that allowed me to publish the TEI-encoded ELTeC documents online. I tried to document and explain not only what I did but also reasoning behind my actions.

I have been working with the setup based on eXist database and used tools and methods I personally find best for the job. There are, nevertheless, other possible solutions, based on alternative technological choices.

section.title: Generate the base app
section.para: A starting point for this application is the TEI Publisher's app generator. TEI Publisher is an open source tool which enables scholars and editors to publish their XML-encoded material in a standard-based, modular, interoperable, and sustainable manner. If you are not familiar with the TEI Publisher, see its documentation to learn more.

With the TEI Publisher you can easily create a complete, standalone application which can be tailored further to fit your needs. The generated app can be downloaded as a portable xar package, to be installed into any eXist-db instance. It provides a fully functional application scaffolding based on TEI Publisher components and modules.
For the ELTeC application I have used Publisher application generator, supplying basic configuration information:

listitem.para: To start with, I have chosen the default TEI Publisher ODD. It contains a set of processing models for TEI elements, recommended by the TEI SimplePrint customization. It seems adequate for not very richly encoded material in ELTeC Level 1 dataset.
In case I will find rendering choices provided by this ODD processing models suboptimal for this project, I can always change the default ODD later.
Application namespace

Every application package in eXist-db needs to have its own unique identifier. This identifier should ideally be a globally unique URI but it doesn't need to correspond to any existing web site. It's a good practice to use a domain name for your project's institution suffixed at least with the project name.

In this case I settled for https://www.distant-reading.net/eltec/level1. www.distant-reading.net/eltec is the existing ELTeC page, so I just suffixed it with /level1 since my application addresses the currently available Level 1 dataset.
Abbreviation

The abbreviation will be used as the name of the root collection of my app. It should be unique within the database instance and must not contain spaces or special characters. I simply chose eltec here.
Title of the application
I simply chose ELTeC European Literary Text Collection. You can choose any title you like.
HTML template
I opted for a standard TEI Publisher template called Default single text layout. I could always change it later if necessary.
Data collection
This is the name of a collection where my application stores its data - in ELTeC's case all the encoded TEI documents.

I simply named the collection data thus deciding to keep my data as part of the application. It is a reasonable choice for distribution, since we'll only have a single package to worry about. ELTeC dataset after reaching mature stage will not be changed (or not too often) so this aspect also suggests to keep data with the app and not in a separate data package.
Default view

This setting defines the default document view - in other words, the default way of navigating through the document. In general case it could be to display the whole document at once or split either page by page or division by division. In ELTeC's case the choice is easy since page divisions are not marked in the encoding, so I chose by division. Bear in mind that this is a default view only: in general users still can change the view settings.
User and password

This setting creates a user for the application which will own all application files. For security reasons, it is advisable to create a new account for every app. Make sure to remember the user and password!

section.para: After filling out the form it was enough to press the Save button and the application has been generated for me within the eXist-db instance. I can open the app from the Dashboard but it doesn't have any data yet so it doesn't look like much at this stage.

section.title: Set up source control with GitHub
section.para: I would like to keep my application in a version control system called git. This will allow me to collaborate with others, keep track of changes to my code and always have an off-site backup for the project.

GitHub is a popular publicly available service for git. I have created a new repository within e-editiones organization and called it eltec. I chose to initialize the repository with a GNU General Public License v.3.0 and a readme file.

figure.title: Create a new repository in GitHub

section.para: As soon as the repository has been created I can clone it to my own computer. Cloning creates a local copy of the repository. I just need to have a git client software installed on my machine.

Since my GitHub repository is public, anyone can execute the git clone command and pull the current state of the files onto their computer. A new directory called eltec will be created in the current working directory with all the content of the remote repository on GitHub.

Similarly, it is possible to update the content of the remote repository with changes made to the local one. Nevertheless, even for a public repository you need to be granted access to write to it. In my case, since I have created the eltec repository I am automatically its owner and have the privilege to push changes to it.

Please note that clone, pull and push are git commands. Simplifying a bit, clone is setting up a local counterpart of a remote repository, pull downloads changes from the remote to the local and push uploads changes from local to the remote repository.

section.title: Synchronize to disk
section.para: In the earlier step, I've created an application package. As a result, the application code is stored in the local eXist database instance. I can access it in a web browser or view the code via eXist's editor called eXide. For the further development though I'd like to work directly on my filesystem and regularly push my code to the GitHub repo. I need to synchronize my application package from the database to the filesystem.
Easy way to do it is to use eXide's XQuery support. I can just execute this simple script to synchronize contents of the database to a directory on the disk:

The file:sync function takes two paths as parameters: first one is the path to the collection in the database and the second the path to the directory in the filesystem. I made sure that the second parameter points to the directory where my git repository is cloned to.

figure.title: Synchronize database collection to the filesystem

section.para: Run the file:sync clicking the Eval button or pressing Cmd+Enter.

The illustration above presents the directory structure after synchronization. You will note the LICENSE and README.md files which were created via GitHub interface and others, generated for me in eXist via TEI Publisher's app generator.
At this point I can stage my changes in git.

In the command above I selected every file and subdirectory to be staged using the * wildcard. Usually you'll want to be more selective and only specify certain changed files. Numerous git clients with a graphic interface exist to assist with this task.

After I have selected all changes I wanted, it's time to commit and push them. The commit action associates all currently staged changes with a short explanatory message I need to provide and saves this state. When I push to the remote repository afterwards, all changes associated with my commit will be uploaded into the remote repository.

section.title: Collect the data
section.para: At this point, I am almost completely set, the only remaining duty is to add actual data. Already filling out the generator's form I have decided to keep all documents within the data collection of my app. Let's have a look at ELTeC's own repository to check what kind of internal organization we're going to need.
ELTeC itself uses GitHub to make their datasets publicly available, which makes my task very easy.

The COST-ELTeC collection groups a number of repositories. Each repository with a name matching the ELTeC-{CODE} hosts dataset for a language with a corresponding ISO 639-3 code, e.g. ELTeC-pol for Polish, ELTeC-eng for English and so on.
Each of these repositories has the same internal structure, where level1 subdirectory contains all TEI files conformant with the ELTeC Level1 guidelines.
I have already created a directory called ELTEC and cloned my eltec repository into it. I can clone all the ELTeC-* repositories there as well:
Obviously, I need to run the git clone command for every language. It's a bit tedious but I only need to do it this once.

section.para: Since the work on data is ongoing, I decide that for now I'll only include languages which reach green conformance score according to this overview: German, English, French, Hungarian, Portuguese, Romanian, Slovenian and Spanish. I'll follow ELTeC's example and create a subdirectory for each language, named according to 3-letter ISO code.
To achieve this, I need to copy contents of level1 subdirectory for each language into corresponding subdirectory in data collection of my app, e.g.:

section.title: Build and deploy
section.para: Since all the operations on the data collection were performed on my computer's filesystem, nothing has changed in the database. Previously we learned how to synchronise from the database to the filesystem, but now we need to reverse the direction to be finally able to view all the ELTeC novels via our app.

There are several ways to do it, let's start with the build and deploy strategy. With all necessary parts of the application now residing in the filesystem, we can just build an application package. Exist-db supports the EXPath packaging system in which all necessary resources: application code and data are bundled together in the form of xar archives.

note.para: To create the xar archive you need to have the ant program installed.

section.para: I already do, so I just move to the directory where my app is stored and run ant command there:
You will see a build report and a new xar file will be created in build subdirectory, e.g. build/eltec-1.0.0.xar.
Use the Upload in the eXist's Package manager to manually deploy the xar in the database (which can take a longer while, since our data package is substantial).

section.title: Initial state of the application
section.para: After successful deployment of the xar package to the database, we can assess the initial state of the app and decide what kind of customizations we are going to need.
Thanks to the TEI Publisher, we have a lot of ground covered out of the box. We can:

listitem.para: browse through the paginated document list,
use the language facet to narrow down the list,
filter the list by title, author or filename,
view each of the documents uploaded,
generate an ePub book or pdf version of any document,
use the full text search option to search for any word or pattern.

section.para: This is a very good start but certainly we could prettify things and add some nifty features here and there.

listitem.para: add some individual touch by using the ELTeC distant reading logo,
add the static About page, to explain the purpose of the project and host this commentary,
extend the facet search, adding ELTeC specific dimensions, e.g. period, length, gender of the author and reprint factor
add a feature for displaying frequency list for a document

section.title: Application styling
section.para: Each of the pages we can visit in a Publisher-based app uses a certain HTML page template. These templates reside in the templates collection. Our start page, the one displaying the document list, is stored in index.html. This is where we need to start if we would like to change anything.
First, I'll just upload an image file to resources/images and add HTML code to insert it into the menubar.

With the code above, the logo unfortunately looks a bit distorted, so I'll have to fix the CSS styling. All TEI Publisher HTML template files import the theme.css stylesheet which specifies application-wide styles. I could change it directly, but a better practice would be rather to import a new, custom CSS file which overwrites selected properties. This way, updating to the new version of Publisher I can import its new theme.css and benefit from default configuration, without worry about losing my customizations.
I will therefore create an eltec.css file and import it in my index.html template.

section.title: Static pages
section.para: As already said, this ELTeC app is conceived as a case study, therefore I'll need a space for this commentary. My idea is to add a link to the menu so it is easy to find. Like with the logo, I will start with the index.html page.
Menubar contains a section which is displayed only on a device with a viewport of at least 1024 pixels wide. This is where I will add my "About" page link.

You will note that the link leads to the commentary/about.html document. Already mentioned in the section we discussed the internal structure of the data directory, I created this subcollection to be able to easily exclude any commentary or other content from ELTeC documents themselves.

section.title: Facets and indexes
section.para: As we have seen, changing the look and feel of the generated app is not too hard, at least if you know basic HTML and some CSS tricks. We'll see that it is perhaps even simpler to customize facets. This subject is covered in general in the TEI Publisher documentation, but I'll discuss here the specifics of the ELTeC data.

All ELTeC documents contain a certain basic set of metadata which we can use to provide a convenient set of facet dimensions for quick filtering of the whole dataset. In particular, it would be good to offer facetted search by language, period, length and perhaps the number of reprints of the work.
section.programlisting: <TEI xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="HU13802" xml:lang="hu"> <teiHeader> <fileDesc> <titleStmt> <title>Magduska öröksége : Regény : ELTeC edition</title> <author ref="viaf:68652301">Abonyi Lajos (1833-1898)</author> ... </titleStmt> <extent> <measure unit="words">52809</measure> <measure unit="pages">133</measure> <measure unit="vols">2</measure> </extent> ... </fileDesc> <profileDesc> <langUsage> <language ident="hu">Hungarian</language> <language ident="la">Latin</language> </langUsage> <textDesc> <authorGender xmlns="http://distantreading.net/eltec/ns" key="M"/> <size xmlns="http://distantreading.net/eltec/ns" key="medium"/> <canonicity xmlns="http://distantreading.net/eltec/ns" key="low"/> <timeSlot xmlns="http://distantreading.net/eltec/ns" key="T3"/> </textDesc> </profileDesc>
section.para: TEI Publisher pre-defines two facets: Genre and Language. We will need to add facets for gender, period, size and reprint. Genre doesn't make very much sense for ELTeC corpus, since all documents are novels, so I'll remove it, in order not to waste the screen space.
There are 3 places which need adjusting for the facet configuration:

listitem.para: modules/config.xqm defines which facets should be displayed by default in the facets panel
collection.xconf stores the index configuration
index.xql stores functions (if any) referenced by collection.xconf

section.para: We cannot use facets until relevant indexes with facet definitions are created. Therefore our first stop will be collection.xconf where we'll be adding new facets.
You will notice there are several facets already defined for the /TEI/text nodes. We'll just add a few more:

Definitions in the collection configuration file are rather short, offloading the work of actually specifying where to get the facet values to the get-metadata() function of the index.xql module. What follows, we need to add handling of the new facets there as well. Since the whole function is basically a switch statement, we'll need add relevant case expressions for each of newly defined facets.

In this step we need to specify XPath (or XQuery) expressions pointing at the data to be used for the facet value. In ELTeC, we'll find them in the textDesc section of the TEI header, in @key attribute of the timeSlot, authorGender, size and canonicity elements, respectively. Please note that these elements are not TEI elements, but belong to a custom http://distantreading.net/eltec/ns namespace.
section.programlisting: declare function idx:get-metadata($root as element(), $field as xs:string) { let $header := $root/tei:teiHeader return switch ($field) ... case "period" return $header//tei:textDesc/*:timeSlot/@key case "gender" return $header//tei:textDesc/*:authorGender/@key case "size" return $header//tei:textDesc/*:size/@key case "reprint" return $header//tei:textDesc/*:canonicity/@key ... default return () };

note.para: Please note that in the index.xql, the function get-metadata is prefixed as idx:get-metadata, while in collection.xconf the same function is referenced as nav:get-metadata. Please remember that the prefix is inconsequential, as long as the actual namespace is the same, in this case http://teipublisher.com/index, as specified in the collection.xconf and index.xql .

section.para: Having adjusted the definitions, I can finally change what is being displayed in the facet sidebar, by tweaking the $config:facets variable in modules/config.xqm. It is a series of maps, one for each facet to be displayed. The pre-defined language facet's configurations looks like this by default:
section.programlisting: map { "dimension": "language", "heading": "facets.language", "max": 5, "hierarchical": false(), "output": function($label) { switch($label) case "en" return "English" case "de" return "German" case "es" return "Spanish" case "fr" return "French" case "en" return "English" default return $label } }
section.para: As we can see it works but some labels show only the language code, while others the correct English name of the language. Reason for this behaviour is the function to handle the displayed label, specified in the output property of our map. We can easily extend the mapping to cover other country codes used in ELTeC, just adding relevant case expressions.
section.programlisting:
case "pt" return "Portuguese" case "pl" return "Polish" case "sl" return "Slovenian" case "ro" return "Romanian" case "hu" return "Hungarian"
(: erroneous but used in ELTec:) case "SPA" return "Spanish"
section.para: Language facet is configured to show no more than 5 most frequent values. I think it would be more convenient for the users to see all available languages at once, so I'll increase the value of the max property to 15.

I am now almost happy with the result, except for the fact that facet counts for different languages exceed number of documents in each language collection. Quick consultation with Lou explains the mystery: default TEI Publisher's configuration uses the @ident attribute on langUsage/language if available, and only falls back to TEI/@xml:lang or teiHeader/@xml:lang if not. ELTeC documents use the langUsage/language to list all languages occurring in the document, which causes the perceived inconsistency.
Solution is simple, adjusting the "recipe" in index.xql to only use @xml:lang:
I need to remember to reindex the collection before my changes are operational but after doing so, the language section in the sidebar finally looks good.

Phew, now we know how to do it, let's repeat for all other facets: gender, period, size and reprint count. We have already prepared the ground in collection.xconf and index.xql so only need to take care of extra maps in config.xqm, e.g. for period we could do it like this:
section.programlisting: map { "dimension": "period", "heading": "Period", "max": 5, "hierarchical": false(), "output": function($label) { switch($label) case "T1" return "1840-59" case "T2" return "1860-79" case "T3" return "1880-99" case "T4" return "1900-20" default return $label } }
section.para: Note how we again use the output property to translate between T1, T2 etc period markers to human readable date spans.

section.title: Internationalization
section.para: Facets sidebar looks good in English, but changing the interface language e.g. to Polish we note that our new facet headings have not been translated. No wonder, since we just hardcoded the English labels in config.xqm.

TEI Publisher's pb-components library provides a number of different language files (currently covering 20 languages) with translations of all labels it uses. In custom application, we'll sooner or later need to define new labels, and if these are supposed to be localized, we'll need our custom language files. Fortunately, TEI Publisher provides a convenient mechanism to add custom labels.
Custom language files need to reside in the resources/i18n/app subcollection. I will create a JSON file for each language and call it after the 2-letter ISO country code with .json extension.

Each of the files has identical JSON structure, only translated labels will differ. My aim is to have ELTeC app available in each of its languages, so I need to ask for help in translations. Fortunately, members of the ELTeC team were very quick to assist.

Final step is to change the hardcoded label into a reference to a language file. This is easy in Publisher, since it will first check if the heading property of a facet matches a label in custom language file. So all I need to do is change the "Period" into eltec.facets.period and so on.
For a more thorough discussion of various internationalization scenarios, see Publisher's documentation.

section.title: Next steps
section.para: We hope this transcript will be useful for some users exploring the world of TEI-based publications. Please get in touch, ideally via TEI Publisher's Slack if you have comments, requests for topics not yet (or not thoroughly enough) covered or have questions regarding your project.
Next in line, we're planning a similar commentary on a parallel edition of 15th century letters. Please also get in touch if you'd like to assist in any way or propose your project for a case study.
